text: The value is a timestamp in ms/milliseconds.

text: getting weird values while converting to minutes...not sure whats the problem

elements.text: getting weird values while converting to minutes...not sure whats the problem

text: Where are you doing the conversion? The value is a timestamp so if you convert that to minutes you’ll get minutes from 1/1/1970 to when it last updated. You’ll need to get the current timestamp in ms, subtract the metric value and convert that to minutes.

elements.text: Where are you doing the conversion? The value is a timestamp so if you convert that to minutes you’ll get minutes
from 1/1/1970 to when it last updated.
You’ll
need to get the current timestamp in ms, subtract the metric value and convert that to minutes.

text: Or something similar.

elements.text: Or something similar.

text: If you’re using Datadog they don’t support timestamps in ms so you’ll need to create a custom check in Python.

elements.text: If
you’re
using Datadog they
don’t
support timestamps in ms so
you’ll
need to create a custom check in Python.

text: Hey <@U0702NSFW0H> - we at Coin Metrics are officially launching our featured app on Monday. I believe our app will perfectly address your need. Our app has two components, network wide metrics (which are probably less relevant to your specific use case) as well as our block explorer product Atlas which creates unified data model and makes it easy to analyze all balance-update of any Canton Coin movement. This is possible based on PartyID, activity ID, timestamp and many other dimensions. Super happy to find time for us to touch base on this and give you a walk through.

elements.text: Hey

- we at Coin Metrics are officially launching our featured app on Monday. I believe our app will perfectly address your need. Our app has two components, network wide metrics (which are probably less relevant to your specific use case) as well as our block explorer product Atlas which creates unified data model and makes it easy to analyze all balance-update of any Canton Coin movement. This is possible based on PartyID, activity ID, timestamp and many other dimensions. Super happy to find time for us to touch base on this and give you a walk through.

text:
this is probably in documentation or an architecture paper somewhere so if anyone can point me to that i would appreciate it - how are party CC balances tracked on the network? say i lost a validator and had no backups and needed to restore it - per the docs at <https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_disaster_recovery.html#re-onboard-a-validator-and-recover-balances-of-all-users-it-hosts> the CC balance and CNS entries can be recovered from the network

to recover that, does it have to rewind back to the very beginning of the timeline and tabulate everything all over again until it gets to the current round, or do the SVs track that running tabulation for each party?

elements.text: this is probably in documentation or an architecture paper somewhere so if anyone can point me to that i would appreciate it - how are party CC balances tracked on the network? say i lost a validator and had no backups and needed to restore it - per the docs at

the CC balance and CNS entries can be recovered from the network

to recover that, does it have to rewind back to the very beginning of the timeline and tabulate everything all over again until it gets to the current round, or do the SVs track that running tabulation for each party?

text:
Coming back to this, we currently try to recover an identity backup made on 0.3.21 while the node is on 0.4.3 and running into a topology error, it says the topology import consistently fails due to the 22-serial gap between backup (serial 1) and network (serial 23) - the network progressed “too much” in the meantime.

Does anyone got experience with backwards compatibility for identity backups?

elements.text:
Coming back to this, we currently try to recover an identity backup made on 0.3.21 while the node is on 0.4.3 and running into a topology error, it says the topology import consistently fails due to the 22-serial gap between backup (serial 1) and network (serial 23) - the network progressed “too much” in the meantime.

Does anyone got experience with backwards compatibility for identity backups?

text:
Trying to deploy Utility using the docker-compose method on MainNet. Went through the doc at <https://docs.digitalasset.com/utilities/0.7/canton-utility-setup/utility-setup-docker-compose.html>. Made necessary changes to .env, compose.yaml and nginx.conf. Created the app in OAuth. When running the start script with:
./start.sh -s "$SPONSOR_SV_URL" -o "" -p "$PARTY_HINT" -m "$MIGRATION_ID" -w -a

I get the following error:
Error response from daemon: Head "<https://digitalasset-canton-network-utility-docker.jfrog.io/v2/frontend/manifests/0.7.4>": unknown: Authentication is required

Is that a permissions issue with the image repository? Or some settings in compose.yaml set incorrectly?

Is that a permissions issue with the image repository? Or some settings in compose.yaml set incorrectly?
